bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, April 12, 1938

div1.p: Andrus summarizes his correspondence with the Mayo Clinic physicians for Moran, and he discusses the film “Yellow Jack.” He describes Lambert's physical condition and comments on the New Deal.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, April 12, 1938

opener.dateline:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
4-12-38

div1.p:
It was mighty nice of you to to interest Dr. Hench in my
case but, I am quite sure, that age, length of illness,
general physical condition, etc., make it hopeless.

The medicos at Mayo Clinic must be an extraordinarily fine
lot of individuals. In reply to letters from my son
and I, Dr. Hench replied, in part: “It is possible that
arthritis may be a very definite factor in your nerve con-
dition but certainly you have more profound nerve changes
than the great majority of people, even with severe arth-
ritis of the spine. The trouble may be a bad combination
of two diseases. It is really impossible for me to say
without the privilege of seeing you, and I hesitate to put
you to the bother and expense of coming here unless we are
sure that we can do something for you. Nevertheless, I
want to see what can be done.”

In addition, I had a letter from Dr. Slocumb, regarding
mattress, and a letter from Dr. Woltman: * * “I have had
no personal experience with yellow fever but I have read
of no complications involving the nervous system that made
their appearance long after the attack of fever ran a pro-
gressive course or suggested the picture you described.”

Was very much interested in what you say about MGM produc-
ing “Yellow Jack”. Had a letter from Gust. E. Lambert,
several weeks ago, saying that the play had been put on in
Chicago two or three performances and that he had been
introduced on the stage.

You will recall Lambert as Dr. Ames' man Friday at the
yellow fever hospital at Columbia Barracks. He and his
wife do the janitor work in a Chicago apartment house.
John D. Schwieger - a former Corps man with whom I served -
tells me that Lambert has extremely poor vision and that
he is badly crippled with rheumatism.

Am enclosing a few comments on the New Deal from which you
may possibly conclude that I do not hold it in the highest
esteem. I presume that you have kept abreast of happen-
ings in the USA. Shall be interested to know what you
think of my conclusions.
